Title: Bridging Europe: A Quaternary Timescale for the Expansion and Evolution of Humans

This proposal seeks to establish a high-resolution chronology for human evolution and migration in Europe during the Quaternary period, spanning the last 2.6 million years. The current limitation of radiocarbon dating (~60,000 years) hinders our understanding of this critical period, and this project aims to bridge this gap by developing a paired dating approach using amino acid dating and thermoluminescence dating on calcitic fossils and snail opercula. 

The proposed research will refine our understanding of European human cultural and population dynamics and their relationship to environmental change over the last 2.6 million years. By addressing critical questions such as the timing of early human expansion into Europe, climatic conditions during human expansion, and differences in tool technologies, this project will provide a nuanced understanding of human evolution and migration in Europe. 

The pan-European chronology developed by this research will be a breakthrough in our ability to understand our past, allowing us to reconstruct the complex interplay between human populations and environmental change during a period marked by climatic oscillations, expansion of ice sheets, sea-level changes, and re-organization of plant and animal communities. By covering regions such as Britain and the Black Sea, this project will provide a comprehensive understanding of the entire Palaeolithic in Eurasia, shedding new light on the history of our species.

This project aims to establish a robust, high-resolution chronology for the expansion and evolution of humans in Europe during the Quaternary period (last 2.6 million years).
